msContents.summary: The earliest-known, probably holograph copy of the Khulāṣat al-Kalām (Essence of Oration), completed by the author, Navvāb Amīn al Dawlah ‘Azīz al-Mulk, ‘Alī Ībrāhīm Khān Bahādur, known as 'Nāṣir Jang', (d. 1793–94), pen-named 'Khayāl'. in 1198 AH (1784 CE). The first of a two-volume anthology of Persian mas̱navī poetry, it contains entries for forty out of seventy-two poets chronicled in the complete work, begining with the letter ālif (الف) to the first page of letter ṣād (صاد), ending here with poet Ḥusaynā Ṣabūḥī (d. 1198 AH 1677–78 CE). He also authored other legal, literary, and historical works, including Aḥvāl-i jang-i Marhattah (Chronicle of the Maratha War), of which the John Rylands Library also holds a copy (Persian MS 452). Originally from Patna, Warren Hastings befriended the author and appointed him Chief Magistrate of Benares (Varanasi today), a post in which he served until his death, during which time he composed this work and dedicated it to Hastings on folio 2b.

msItem.title: Khulāṣat al-kalām
خلاصة الكلام
msItem.incipit: برگ ۱پ (folio 1b): تعالی الله ما قصیر فهما کوتاه بیان را چه یارا که زبان حمد و ثنا متکلم بی زبان توانیم گشود.
msItem.explicit: برگ ۴۰۵پ (folio 405b): برگ ۴۰پ: نگین دان فیروزه آسمان.
msItem.colophon: The volume lacks a true colophon, but the author indicates the date he completed the work in Benares (Varanasi), India in 1198 AH (1784 CE) at the end of his introduction at the top of folio 2b. While the author did not explicitly sign this volume, he likely did on the now-missing second volume. However, hand clearly matches another manuscript that he completed, Tuḥfat al-Hind (Gift of India), formerly held in the Royal Society Library, later transferred to the British Library, (RSPA 78), which inscription on the flyleaf states that Navvab ‘Ali Ibrahim Khan Bahadur presented it to Sir William Jones in 1199 AH (1784 CE), with an adjacent seal impression engraved with his full name, dated 1783 AH CE.
msItem.note: While John Bardoe Elliott (1785–1863) reports in letters to Nathaniel Bland and Aloys Sprenger that the author employed the pen-names of 'Khalīl' and Ḥāl; however, he gives another name of 'Khayāl' at the top of folio 2a (see Bland and Sprenger catalogue).
For a complete description of the work, see the ‘Abd al-Muqtadir catalogue, nos. 705–706.

support.p: Textblock comprised of sized and polished ivory-coloured paper handmade in India.

foliation.p: Foliation marked at top-centre of the a sides in Hindu-Arabic numerals, with later Arabic numerals in pencil starting on the second flyleaf. Note this record follows the Hindu-Arabic numberals.

supportDesc.collation: Undetermined. Catchwords on b side of nearly every folio.

condition.p: Fair condition. Rodent-eaten along the fore-edge and head, leaving cavities similar to indexing cuts. Folios 60-106 repaired or extended along the foredge, and prior tissue repairs applied to insect damaged areas.

layout.p: Written in 4 columns with 25 lines per page. Pages ruled with a misṭarah hand guide.

handNote.desc: In the hand of the author, ʻAlī Ibrāhīm Khān, (d. 1793–94), in nasta'liq script in black with titles, sub-headings, and the names of poets in red.

list.item: Marginalia: Infrequent marginalia in the hand of the copyist/compiler, ʻAlī Ibrāhīm Khān, (d. 1793–94).

binding.p: Sewn on seven supports, with three laced into the pasteboards, then covered in full black goatskin leather Spine later rebacked, tight-backed in brown goatskin leather, with blind-tooled palette lines by the raised bands. Internal leather doublures of dark red goatskin, with later hand-coloured paperflyleaves likely added when the volume was rebacked.

decoNote.p: Board perimetres ruled in thin and thick lines with gold ink, the wider one repeatedly stamped with rows of insular dots in rows.

binding.condition: Good condition, but tight opening to the gutter.

physDesc.accMat: Accompanied by a folded loose sheet of blue European handmade paper, inscribed with list in English, in the hand of Nathaniel Bland, naming the poets featured.

history.origin: Benares (Varanasi), India1198 AH (1784 CE), in the 27th year of the reign of Shāh ‘Ālam II (r. 1760–88; 1788–1806), as indicated by the author at the end of his introduction on folio 2b.

provenance.p: Presented to the Royal Asiatic Society of Great Britain and Ireland] by Sir John Malcolm (1769–1833) on 19 May 1827.

Evidently borrowed from the library by Persian scholar Nathaniel Bland (1803-1865), likely in preparation for his essay, but then never returned before his death. London antiquarian dealer Antiquarian bookseller Bernard Quaritch (1819–1899) then sold the volume with the rest of Bland's collection to Alexander Lindsay, 25th Earl of Crawford (1812–1880) in 1866.
Purchased by Enriqueta Rylands (1843–1908) in 1901 from James Ludovic Lindsay, 26th Earl of Crawford (1847–1913).

acquisition.p: Bequeathed by Enriqueta Rylands (1843–1908) in 1908 to the John Rylands Library.
